8.79.text: I was bar mitzvahed with a stolen torah.

17.77.text:
Burned into my 13-year-old psyche is the drive
to the very fancy former synagogue in Beverly

24.74.text:
Hills that we used to belong to where we all
jumped out of the car, my father and his friend

29.39.text:
and I ran in, leaving the car running and
the trunk open, grabbing the torah, throwing

34.73.text: it into the trunk, and taking off.

38.11.text: The torah did get returned after my bar mitzvah.

40.51.text:
But that maybe gives you a little sense of
sort of who I am.

44.18.text: I tell that story for two reasons.

45.29.text:
One, because I think the statute of limitations
has now expired.

49.04.text:
And also because I think that's -- a little
bit maybe informs perhaps some of what we

54.19.text: do and how we approach it.

59.56.text:
Well, as a group, well, we're a group of engineers,
scientists.

65.79.text:
But we're also -- we have roboticists, molecular
gastronomists, just an amazing collection

79.65.text:
of people who have really awesome day jobs
and who often take time off to spend some

84.90.text:
time with us and create really extraordinary
stuff.

88.65.text:
We've been called the League of Extraordinary
Nerds by Fast Company.

93.16.text:
We've also called ourselves a drinking club
with an art problem.

96.28.text:
[ Laughter ]
>>Adam Sadowsky: But mostly, and perhaps fundamentally,

102.98.text:
And we tell our stories with kinetic sculpture
and interactive art.

108.56.text:
And we're going to show you a little bit about
what it is that we do.

111.96.text:
This is just a quick look at a piece we did
a couple years ago in Santa Monica for a festival,

116.77.text: a nighttime festival with all glowing art.

119.92.text:
We had a vision of creating a piece made of
a double helix with full color LEDs, and connected

131.13.text:
And we gave a button panel to the audience
and let them decide what light sequences they

136.70.text:
We, of course, allowed the music -- we filtered
the music through this system as well so that

144.04.text:
we would always beat-match so the light was
always matching whatever the deejay was playing.

148.37.text: It was a really beautiful piece.

151.77.text:
We were asked to do some work for work for
the folks at Die Hard battery.

155.00.text:
And their only question of us was, "What can
you do to show how tough our batteries are?"

161.77.text: We said, "Will it take a bullet?"

164.98.text: They gave us a half a dozen.

166.43.text: We took them to the desert.

168.00.text: And you can see a bullet in flight there.

178.22.text:
In fact, that actually did start a car afterwards,
if you can believe it.

187.52.text:
We also, as part of the same campaign, built
them an organ made out of automobiles, arranged

193.47.text:
like a piano keyboard, ran all the power back
to a single Die Hard battery, and ran all

199.97.text:
the lights and horns back to a computer connected
to a mini keyboard.

203.64.text: And we had Gary Numan playing.

That was Gary Numan playing his song "Cars"

>>Adam Sadowsky: So, by the way, as smart

250.33.text:
as this group of really talented individuals

259.79.text:
We did some work for Chevy, keeping with the
car theme, actually, totally accidentally.

263.39.text:
They approached us with the launch of the
new Sonic last year.

269.59.text:
The resulting spot actually aired during the
Super Bowl, which was a huge, exciting win

274.75.text: I'll let this one speak for itself.

278.44.text:
]
>>> On October 19th, 2011, we asked the Internet

283.25.text:
to help launch the all new Chevy Sonic from
a 100-foot platform.

288.35.text: The launch was streamed live on Let'sDoThis.com.

293.18.text:
To help push, the only thing you had to do
was to click on a four-foot closer hand.

298.31.text:
Every additional click turned an elaborate
gear system in real time and pushed the Sonic

302.66.text: closer and closer to the edge.

306.18.text:
You could check out the launch from any angle
you wanted, from gear cam to (indiscernible)

311.48.text: cam, even sit inside the Sonic itself.

315.72.text:
And while you waited for the car to drop,
you could go back in time and check the click

320.60.text: stats to see who else was pushing.

324.78.text:
After nine hours and 2.5 million clicks, this
happened.

339.95.text:
]
>>Adam Sadowsky: So it was a 36-inch tolerance.

345.59.text:
We couldn't hit the ground and we had to hit
a water on a 100-foot bungee jump with a car.

354.38.text:
What we're perhaps most famous for is, of
course, Rube Goldberg machines, which we love,

358.28.text:
being that we're from the Wile E. Coyote school
of engineering.

363.77.text:
One of the most famous is a machine we did
for OK Go.

366.82.text:
I'm not going to show you the whole thing,
but a few seconds for those who haven't seen

372.72.text:
it or who need a refresher on what it is we
did.

396.71.text:
]
>>Adam Sadowsky: Sorry that I can't play more

408.44.text: This is one we did for Google Science Fair.

422.91.text:
That's very nice, but I'm running out of time,
so you can't applaud anymore.

501.68.text:
One of the things that, actually, really resonated
with me yesterday was something that JJ Abrams

507.33.text:
Actually, he mentioned it a couple of times,
the idea that the sort of unlimited possibility

511.21.text: kind of paralyzes you in your creative process.

515.62.text:
That's certainly true for us, because sometimes
a brand or a band or someone will come to

520.31.text: us and just say, what do we do?

523.88.text:
And so for us, having the opportunity to do
that is really exciting, but we need to sort

529.41.text:
of wrap what we call enabling constraints,
a phrase that was coined by my associate in

533.98.text:
the back, Brett Dorr, who I will introduce
in a moment more officially.

538.40.text:
We basically put these things in, sometimes
artificially, sometimes budget related, whatever,

543.40.text: to help us sort of guide our creative process.

545.65.text: We find it incredibly valuable for us.

549.06.text:
We believe that art reflects the tools of
the time and that, you know, we feel like

553.90.text:
the tools are just getting better and better
every day.

556.97.text:
That technology is enabling us in all kinds
of really exciting ways.

560.04.text:
We believe that technology plus creativity
equals art and innovation.

563.41.text:
I don't think there's anyone in the room who
will disagree with that concept, but that's

567.01.text: sort of a guiding principle for us.

568.80.text:
Finally, we believe that authenticity is really
important.

572.64.text:
I think that's sort of a running thread through
all of our work.

575.70.text:
We really believe that there's a place for
the authentic.

579.81.text:
CG certainly has its place, it's brilliant,
wonderful, we can create the unimaginable.

585.35.text:
But there's something really wonderful about
seeing the magic of actual things happening

591.00.text:
And so with that, let me introduce my associate
in the back, officially now, Brett Dorr, who

596.82.text:
is one of our lead engineers, he's standing
by the contraption that's been there for the

602.57.text:
The secret here is that we're going to be
actually demonstrating a small Rube Goldberg

608.41.text:
machine live, a machine that Brett built over
the last day, basically in the parking lot.

614.15.text:
So we're -- Brett, why don't I let you explain
it?

621.78.text:
Going to roll a ball down this little track
that's going to whack into this hammer.

626.77.text:
The hammer is going to flip, it's going to
whack into the ice axe.

630.39.text:
The ice axe is going to flip, it's going to
hit this hook.

633.45.text: It is going to whip the pen out of the screwdriver.

637.96.text:
The screwdriver is going to fall about five
feet and land in this funnel.

644.77.text:
That's about -- about -- that's about four
inches wide.

649.97.text:
It's going to go into the center of the funnel
and it's going to connect to this little switch.

654.60.text: That's going to turn on this belt sander.

657.98.text:

reel up and it's going to take up this string

674.27.text:
That string is going to pull this little arm
up, which will pull a pin out of this right

681.84.text:
The door is going to swing open, the sander
is going to shoot down this little track.

685.83.text:
It's going to whack into that sledge hammer
--

687.55.text:

>>> But it's going to whack into the sledge
hammer, the sledge hammer is going to drop.

699.66.text: It's going to pull that little pump.

702.61.text:
The pump is going to blow a little gust of
air against that golf ball, the golf ball

708.16.text: is going to roll down the track.

709.51.text: It's going to hop into that, this little cup.

712.44.text: The cup is going to drop.

713.62.text: It's going to fall into the other cup.

715.56.text:
That little cup is going to drop, it's going
to pull the pin out of that lever.

718.93.text:
It's going to drop the olive into the martini
glass.

727.58.text:
>>Adam Sadowsky: -- let me just say the failure

734.29.text:
We did 82 takes for the OK Go video and got
